Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Sprinkle \Sprin"kle\ (spr[i^][ng]"k'l), v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Sprinkled} (-k'ld); p. pr. & vb. n. {Sprinkling} (-kl[i^]ng).] [OE. sprenkelen, freq. of sprengen to sprinkle, to scatter, AS. sprengan, properly, to make to spring, causative of springan to spring; akin to D. sprenkelen to sprinkle, G. sprengen. See {Spring}, v. i., and cf. {Sprent}.] 1. To scatter in small drops or particles, as water, seed, etc. [1913 Webster]
2. To scatter on; to disperse something over in small drops or particles; to besprinkle; as, to sprinkle the earth with water; to sprinkle a floor with sand. [1913 Webster]
3. To baptize by the application of a few drops, or a small quantity, of water; hence, to cleanse; to purify. [1913 Webster]
Having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience. --Heb. x. 22. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Sprinkling \Sprin"kling\ (-kl[i^]ng), n. 1. The act of one who, or that which, sprinkles. [1913 Webster]
Baptism may well enough be performed by sprinkling or effusion of water. --Ayliffe. [1913 Webster]
2. A small quantity falling in distinct drops or particles; as, a sprinkling of rain or snow. [1913 Webster]
3. Hence, a moderate number or quantity distributed like separate drops, or as if scattered like drops. --Craik. [1913 Webster]

sprinkling n 1: a small number dispersed haphazardly; "the first scatterings of green" [syn: {scattering}] 2: a light shower that falls in some locations and not others nearby [syn: {scattering}, {sprinkle}] 3: the act of sprinkling water in baptism (rare) [syn: {aspersion}] 4: the act of sprinkling or splashing water; "baptized with a sprinkling of holy water"; "a sparge of warm water over the malt" [syn: {sprinkle}, {sparge}]
